ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 111 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 111 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: This class was really interesting! There's really something here for everyone - race issues, environmental issues, architecture and urban planning, energy politics, history, art, etc etc. I really, really enjoyed the readings; there was a fair amount, but it was my favorite homework because they were so interesting (for example, you read about urban exploring in Detroit, meth in small-town america, and how to label nuclear energy reserves for future generations). When I took it, the class was tiny, just 5 people. That was a little challenging for a 2-hour seminar because you really had to be on top of your game, no one can slide by - but obviously this will vary semester to semester. I think this was the first time it was taught, so it'll probably grow by next spring. Chloe is really approachable, sweet, and gives a lot of great feedback, but she's not the best at leading discussion. Sometimes it felt like we were just asking lots of questions and providing no answers, which I guess is something that happens in most seminars like this. However, I really enjoyed the diversity of the material covered, and the work is super manageable (reading responses every week, short paper, long final paper, and 2 short presentations in class). I'd also never taken such a small class, and really enjoyed the experience - it felt like a really open and low-risk environment for discussion.

Yes! Super fun and you discuss important implications about issues that are extremely relevant today. Definitely changed my perspective on urban development; I don't think I will be able to see cities the same without questioning underlying legacies and future implications.
